elements.content: Here, we prepared a cobalt–metal organic framework (MOF) by anodic electrodeposition at room temperature and transformed it first to Co3O4 by calcination. The MOF-derived Co3O4 was then employed as a sacrificial template to fabricate CoSe films via anion exchange with a NaHSe medium. Electrodeposited MOF films showed a uniform and well-defined dodecahedral morphology with a particle size in the 3–4 μm range. The MOF-derived Co3O4 retained the original dodecahedral morphology, and these morphological features were essentially preserved in CoSe derived from the Co3O4 template via anion exchange. Both the parent oxide and the chalcogenide were characterized by a variety of spectroscopic and microscopic methods. The MOF-derived CoSe was demonstrated as a nonenzymatic glucose sensor with an analytical sensitivity of 1423.9 μA mM–1 cm–2 and a lower detection limit of 1.53 μM.
elements.clean_text: Here, we prepared a cobalt-metal organic framework (MOF) by anodic electrodeposition at room temperature and transformed it first to Co3O4 by calcination. The MOF-derived Co3O4 was then employed as a sacrificial template to fabricate CoSe films via anion exchange with a NaHSe medium. Electrodeposited MOF films showed a uniform and well-defined dodecahedral morphology with a particle size in the 3-4 μm range. The MOF-derived Co3O4 retained the original dodecahedral morphology, and these morphological features were essentially preserved in CoSe derived from the Co3O4 template via anion exchange. Both the parent oxide and the chalcogenide were characterized by a variety of spectroscopic and microscopic methods. The MOF-derived CoSe was demonstrated as a nonenzymatic glucose sensor with an analytical sensitivity of 1423.9 μA mM-1 cm-2 and a lower detection limit of 1.53 μM.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted much attention due to their large surface area, regular pore sizes and shapes, diverse structural topologies, and chemical tunability. However, they have been mostly prepared via time-inefficient methods that require days or hours to develop the MOFs. Electrochemical approaches to preparing MOFs have the advantages of short synthesis times, mild conditions, process simplicity, and amenability to scale up. Importantly, they also yield the MOFs in the film form, compatible with many applications such as energy conversion, chemical sensing, or microelectronics. Both anodic and cathodic electrodeposition can be used as demonstrated by previous authors.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted much attention due to their large surface area, regular pore sizes and shapes, diverse structural topologies, and chemical tunability. However, they have been mostly prepared via time-inefficient methods that require days or hours to develop the MOFs. Electrochemical approaches to preparing MOFs have the advantages of short synthesis times, mild conditions, process simplicity, and amenability to scale up. Importantly, they also yield the MOFs in the film form, compatible with many applications such as energy conversion, chemical sensing, or microelectronics. Both anodic and cathodic electrodeposition can be used as demonstrated by previous authors.

elements.content: The major differentiating aspect of this study is the fact that we were able to secure a very definite and regular dodecahedral morphology for the zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs) on polycrystalline Au or fluorine-doped tin oxide (FTO) electrode surfaces. The deposition nuances could also be teased out via electrochemical quartz crystal microgravimetry (EQCM).
elements.clean_text: The major differentiating aspect of this study is the fact that we were able to secure a very definite and regular dodecahedral morphology for the zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs) on polycrystalline Au or fluorine-doped tin oxide (FTO) electrode surfaces. The deposition nuances could also be teased out via electrochemical quartz crystal microgravimetry (EQCM).

elements.content: Finally, we demonstrate that the Co-ZIF-67 can be used to prepare cobalt selenide via anion exchange of the thermally derived cobalt oxide as a precursor (see ). Cobalt selenide has a variety of applications ranging from use as a counter electrode in photoelectrochemical cells, as an electrocatalyst for dioxygen and hydrogen evolution, to use as a visible-light absorber in photovoltaic solar cells.
elements.clean_text: Finally, we demonstrate that the Co-ZIF-67 can be used to prepare cobalt selenide via anion exchange of the thermally derived cobalt oxide as a precursor (see ). Cobalt selenide has a variety of applications ranging from use as a counter electrode in photoelectrochemical cells, as an electrocatalyst for dioxygen and hydrogen evolution, to use as a visible-light absorber in photovoltaic solar cells.

elements.content: Schematic of the sequential generation of CoSe from the ZIF-67 and oxide precursors.
elements.clean_text: 1  Schematic of the sequential generation of CoSe from the ZIF-67 and oxide precursors.

elements.content: A shows a linear sweep voltammogram (black line) along with frequency changes (red line) for a cobalt film electrode in a 0.1 M Na2SO4 blank electrolyte. The cobalt film was pre-electrodeposited on the Au electrode at a potential of −1.0 V in a 0.1 M Na2SO4 electrolyte containing 20 mM Co­(CH3COO)2 until the EQCM frequency changed to ∼3000 Hz. The pH of the blank electrolyte was adjusted to 10.8, the pH of a 0.1 M Na2SO4 electrolyte containing 1 M 2-methylimidazole (2-MeIm), which was used for the synthesis of ZIF-67 films. During the anodic scan, the frequency increase (mass decrease) started at ∼0.4 V, coinciding with the anodic wave, and no frequency change was observed after ∼1.0 V. The anodic wave at ∼0.7 V is due to oxidation of cobalt to cobalt (II) ions, which is manifested in the frequency increase (mass decrease) that occurred with the anodic current.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

 A shows a linear sweep voltammogram (black line) along with frequency changes (red line) for a cobalt film electrode in a 0.1 M Na2SO4 blank electrolyte. The cobalt film was pre-electrodeposited on the Au electrode at a potential of -1.0 V in a 0.1 M Na2SO4 electrolyte containing 20 mM Co(CH3COO)2 until the EQCM frequency changed to ~3000 Hz. The pH of the blank electrolyte was adjusted to 10.8, the pH of a 0.1 M Na2SO4 electrolyte containing 1 M 2-methylimidazole (2-MeIm), which was used for the synthesis of ZIF-67 films. During the anodic scan, the frequency increase (mass decrease) started at ~0.4 V, coinciding with the anodic wave, and no frequency change was observed after ~1.0 V. The anodic wave at ~0.7 V is due to oxidation of cobalt to cobalt (II) ions, which is manifested in the frequency increase (mass decrease) that occurred with the anodic current.

elements.content: Linear sweep voltammograms (black line) along with EQCM frequency changes (red line) for a cobalt film electrode in a 0.1 M Na2SO4 blank electrolyte (pH = 10.8) (A) without and (B) with 1 M 2-MeIm. Scan rate: 20 mV/s.
elements.clean_text: 2  Linear sweep voltammograms (black line) along with EQCM frequency changes (red line) for a cobalt film electrode in a 0.1 M Na2SO4 blank electrolyte (pH = 10.8) (A) without and (B) with 1 M 2-MeIm. Scan rate: 20 mV/s.

elements.content: Unlike the mass decrease in A, the voltammogram obtained with a cobalt-modified electrode in a 0.1 M Na2SO4 electrolyte containing 1 M 2-MeIm showed a frequency decrease or mass uptake (B). As shown in the figure, the frequency change started at the same potential of ∼0.4 V as in the voltammogram obtained in a blank electrolyte, which implied that the anodic current and concomitant mass increase can be assigned to the oxidation of cobalt to Co2+. The Co2+ ions then react with 2-MeIm in the electrolyte to generate the ZIF-67 film, which is very similar to the anodic synthesis of Cu–BTC using a Cu electrode in a BTC-containing electrolyte. Also, the amount of frequency change in B was larger than in A, again supporting formation of a ZIF-67 coating on the electrode. The frequency changes in A,B were mirror images, demonstrating formation of the MOF film on the electrode. Interestingly, a monotonic current increase instead of a current peak was seen in B. This is attributable to the blocking effect of ZIF-67 formed on the cobalt film that inhibits oxidation of cobalt. Neither 2-MeIm nor the 0.1 M Na2SO4 electrolyte showed a substantial anodic currents as well as frequency changes (Figure S1).
elements.clean_text: Unlike the mass decrease in A, the voltammogram obtained with a cobalt-modified electrode in a 0.1 M Na2SO4 electrolyte containing 1 M 2-MeIm showed a frequency decrease or mass uptake (B). As shown in the figure, the frequency change started at the same potential of ~0.4 V as in the voltammogram obtained in a blank electrolyte, which implied that the anodic current and concomitant mass increase can be assigned to the oxidation of cobalt to Co2+. The Co2+ ions then react with 2-MeIm in the electrolyte to generate the ZIF-67 film, which is very similar to the anodic synthesis of Cu-BTC using a Cu electrode in a BTC-containing electrolyte. Also, the amount of frequency change in B was larger than in A, again supporting formation of a ZIF-67 coating on the electrode. The frequency changes in A,B were mirror images, demonstrating formation of the MOF film on the electrode. Interestingly, a monotonic current increase instead of a current peak was seen in B. This is attributable to the blocking effect of ZIF-67 formed on the cobalt film that inhibits oxidation of cobalt. Neither 2-MeIm nor the 0.1 M Na2SO4 electrolyte showed a substantial anodic currents as well as frequency changes (Figure S1).

elements.content: ZIF-67 films were electrodeposited on the cobalt-modified FTO electrode at a potential of 0.5 V in a 0.1 M Na2SO4 electrolyte containing 1 M 2-MeIm at room temperature. The cobalt-modified FTO electrode was prepared at −1.0 V for 1 h using 0.1 M Na2SO4 containing 20 mM Co­(CH3COO)2. shows SEM images of the as-electrodeposited ZIF-67. It is clearly observed that ZIF-67 particles have uniform size distribution in the 3–4 μm range with a well-defined dodecahedral morphology. A magnified image of a single particle reveals that it has a single crystal-like dodecahedron morphology (B). This feature contrasts with previous reports on the electrosynthesis of ZIF or other MOF particles, which showed a much less-defined morphology. Notably, in this study, the well-defined morphology of ZIF-67 films was secured via electrodeposition at room temperature using an aqueous electrolyte. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first example of an electrodeposition approach for the synthesis of ZIF-67 films with a well-defined rhombic dodecahedral morphology.
elements.clean_text: ZIF-67 films were electrodeposited on the cobalt-modified FTO electrode at a potential of 0.5 V in a 0.1 M Na2SO4 electrolyte containing 1 M 2-MeIm at room temperature. It is clearly observed that ZIF-67 particles have uniform size distribution in the 3-4 μm range with a well-defined dodecahedral morphology. A magnified image of a single particle reveals that it has a single crystal-like dodecahedron morphology (B). This feature contrasts with previous reports on the electrosynthesis of ZIF or other MOF particles, which showed a much less-defined morphology. Notably, in this study, the well-defined morphology of ZIF-67 films was secured via electrodeposition at room temperature using an aqueous electrolyte. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first example of an electrodeposition approach for the synthesis of ZIF-67 films with a well-defined rhombic dodecahedral morphology.

elements.content: The X-ray diffraction (XRD) data () were consistent with the exceedingly well-defined crystallinity and morphology of the Co-based MOF film. These data in the 2-theta range of 5–40o match well with the published results for ZIF-67 films prepared by other methods (cf., refs , , and ).

elements.content: The data in , however, do indicate the presence of unconverted cobalt in the film. This observation necessitated a detailed examination of the effects of thickness of the cobalt film, anodization time, potential, and concentration of 2-MeIm on the morphology and crystallinity of the electrosynthesized particles. A range of potentials was employed to synthesize ZIF-67 films on the cobalt-modified FTO electrode in the 1 M 2-MeIm-containing electrolyte. Figure S2 reveals that deposition potentials ranging from 0.5 to 0.8 V showed no substantial differences in size and shapes of ZIF-67; therefore, a deposition potential of 0.5 V was utilized for the electrosynthesis of ZIF-67 films.

This observation necessitated a detailed examination of the effects of thickness of the cobalt film, anodization time, potential, and concentration of 2-MeIm on the morphology and crystallinity of the electrosynthesized particles. A range of potentials was employed to synthesize ZIF-67 films on the cobalt-modified FTO electrode in the 1 M 2-MeIm-containing electrolyte. Figure S2 reveals that deposition potentials ranging from 0.5 to 0.8 V showed no substantial differences in size and shapes of ZIF-67; therefore, a deposition potential of 0.5 V was utilized for the electrosynthesis of ZIF-67 films.

elements.content: Unlike this variable, the concentration of 2-MeIm had a significant effect on the morphology of the particles (). When the concentration of 2-MeIm was less than 0.5 M, the ZIF-67 particles were not fully grown and were less-defined in shape. The deposition time affected the morphology of the particles, and more than 30 min was required for the substantial oxidation of the cobalt film to result in ZIF-67 particles at 0.5 V in a 0.1 M Na2SO4 electrolyte containing 1 M 2-MeIm (). Shorter deposition time produced incomplete oxidation of cobalt and less-defined particles on the electrode.

Shorter deposition time produced incomplete oxidation of cobalt and less-defined particles on the electrode.

elements.content: For example, many voids were observed at a deposition time of 15 min or 30 min (Figure S3), and therefore, a deposition time of 1 h was used for the electrosynthesis. As in the cathodic electrosynthesis approach that controls deposition time to change thickness, SEM cross-sectional views () reveal that the thickness of the ZIF-67 films does depend on the cobalt film precursor thickness and thence on the deposition time. As indicated by the XRD data in above, incomplete stripping of cobalt films occurred with the thicker films. This is not considered a problem for practical applications since the metal phase may have catalytic attributes. However, we note that methods do exist for selective removal of the metal phase if needed.

elements.content: FT-IR spectroscopy using the KBr pellet technique was employed to identify functional groups and formation of ZIF-67. The appearance of a new band at 426 cm–1 is attributed to the Co–N stretching vibration and disappearance of bands due to N–H bending and stretching, suggesting again the successful electrosynthesis of ZIF-67 ().

The appearance of a new band at 426 cm-1 is attributed to the Co-N stretching vibration and disappearance of bands due to N-H bending and stretching, suggesting again the successful electrosynthesis of ZIF-67 ().

elements.clean_text: 7  FT-IR spectra of 2-methylimidazole (red line) and electrosynthesized ZIF-67 (black line).

elements.content: MOFs have been utilized as sacrificial templates or precursors for fabricating porous nanostructured materials via thermal decomposition. Previous reports revealed that the thermal treatment of ZIF-67 in N2 or Ar gas produced Co3O4 with the original polyhedral morphology since the carbon generated during calcination effectively prevents further contraction of ZIF-67. Therefore, based on these reports and our TGA results (Figure S4), the as-synthesized ZIF-67 template was annealed in N2 at 450 °C and then in air at the same temperature to obtain Co3O4. The XRD and SEM data (Figures S5 and S6) were consistent with the fact that the original MOF morphology was essentially preserved after calcination. The XRD data also match well with published patterns for Co3O4.
elements.clean_text: MOFs have been utilized as sacrificial templates or precursors for fabricating porous nanostructured materials via thermal decomposition. Previous reports revealed that the thermal treatment of ZIF-67 in N2 or Ar gas produced Co3O4 with the original polyhedral morphology since the carbon generated during calcination effectively prevents further contraction of ZIF-67. Therefore, based on these reports and our TGA results (Figure S4), the as-synthesized ZIF-67 template was annealed in N2 at 450 °C and then in air at the same temperature to obtain Co3O4. The XRD and SEM data (Figures S5 and S6) were consistent with the fact that the original MOF morphology was essentially preserved after calcination. The XRD data also match well with published patterns for Co3O4.

elements.content: For the synthesis of CoSe using MOF-derived Co3O4, a NaHSe solution (as a selenium source) was obtained by heating 50 mL of a 0.2 M NaOH solution containing 0.04 g of Se powder and 0.6 g of rongalite at 80 °C until all Se powder was converted to selenide. After cooling to room temperature, the Co3O4 template deposited on the FTO substrate was dipped into the NaHSe solution to fabricate the CoSe film. The SEM images in A,B revealed that the dodecahedral morphology of ZIF-derived Co3O4 was well-retained in CoSe after anion exchange. EDX analyses of the film showed CoSe with an atomic mass ratio of 1:1 (Figure S7A). Also, EDX elemental maps showed that Co and Se elements were uniformly distributed in the CoSe nanostructure (Figure S7B,C). The HR-TEM image in revealed a well-defined crystalline structure with lattice fringes of 0.20 and 0.31 nm, corresponding to the values of the (102) and (100) planes of CoSe planes, respectively.
elements.clean_text: For the synthesis of CoSe using MOF-derived Co3O4, a NaHSe solution (as a selenium source) was obtained by heating 50 mL of a 0.2 M NaOH solution containing 0.04 g of Se powder and 0.6 g of rongalite at 80 °C until all Se powder was converted to selenide. After cooling to room temperature, the Co3O4 template deposited on the FTO substrate was dipped into the NaHSe solution to fabricate the CoSe film. The SEM images in A,B revealed that the dodecahedral morphology of ZIF-derived Co3O4 was well-retained in CoSe after anion exchange. EDX analyses of the film showed CoSe with an atomic mass ratio of 1:1 (Figure S7A). Also, EDX elemental maps showed that Co and Se elements were uniformly distributed in the CoSe nanostructure (Figure S7B,C). The HR-TEM image in  revealed a well-defined crystalline structure with lattice fringes of 0.20 and 0.31 nm, corresponding to the values of the (102) and (100) planes of CoSe planes, respectively.

elements.content: Further evidence for the surface composition of the CoSe films was obtained from XPS, as shown in Figure S8. For the Co 2p spectrum (Figure S8A), the binding energies at 780.8 and 796.8 eV can be assigned to Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2, respectively, revealing the Co2+ oxidation state. The Se 3d spectrum in Figure S8B showed two peaks centered at 54.5 and 59.6 eV, which are assigned to Se 3d5/2 and Se 3d3/2, respectively.
elements.clean_text: Further evidence for the surface composition of the CoSe films was obtained from XPS, as shown in Figure S8. For the Co 2p spectrum (Figure S8A), the binding energies at 780.8 and 796.8 eV can be assigned to Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2, respectively, revealing the Co2+ oxidation state. The Se 3d spectrum in Figure S8B showed two peaks centered at 54.5 and 59.6 eV, which are assigned to Se 3d5/2 and Se 3d3/2, respectively.

elements.content: The CoSe generated in situ was presumably amorphous, judging from the fact it was XRD silent. Interestingly, no XRD signal from any residual cobalt oxide was seen in the present study, signaling that the in situ conversion to the chalcogenide was complete. This finding agrees with that of previous authors on the ion exchange conversion of Co3O4 to CoS in a sodium sulfide medium, which was found to proceed to completion. Direct conversion of Co–MOF to CoSe–MOF was attempted but without success because of the poor mechanical strength of Co–MOF. Contrastingly, Co3O4–MOF was strong enough to withstand the conversion to CoSe–MOF ().
elements.clean_text: The CoSe generated in situ was presumably amorphous, judging from the fact it was XRD silent. Interestingly, no XRD signal from any residual cobalt oxide was seen in the present study, signaling that the in situ conversion to the chalcogenide was complete. This finding agrees with that of previous authors on the ion exchange conversion of Co3O4 to CoS in a sodium sulfide medium, which was found to proceed to completion. Direct conversion of Co-MOF to CoSe-MOF was attempted but without success because of the poor mechanical strength of Co-MOF. Contrastingly, Co3O4-MOF was strong enough to withstand the conversion to CoSe-MOF ().

elements.content: As one example of the practical applicability of the MOF-derived CoSe sample, its performance as a glucose amperometric sensor is presented. displays the amperometric response of CoSe films to glucose at a constant potential of 0.5 V. The CoSe electrode was previously fabricated by the procedure described above. As shown in , successive additions of glucose to the 0.1 M NaOH solution increased the oxidation current, instantly reaching a stable response in each case in less than ∼10 s. The analytical sensitivity was calculated from the slope of a calibration plot (not shown) and was estimated to be 1423.9 μA mM–1 cm–2. This value is ∼3 times higher than a previous result for a CoSe nanoflake-decorated reduced graphene oxide electrode. A limit of detection (LOD) value (defined at a S/N ration of 3) of 1.53 μM was obtained, which is also better than previous results. The improved performance of the CoSe electrode described in this study can be ascribed to the fact that no binder was used for the preparation of the CoSe film on the electrode surface. Also, increased active sites due to the porous structure may enhance the performance of the electrode toward glucose oxidation.
elements.clean_text: As one example of the practical applicability of the MOF-derived CoSe sample, its performance as a glucose amperometric sensor is presented.  displays the amperometric response of CoSe films to glucose at a constant potential of 0.5 V. The CoSe electrode was previously fabricated by the procedure described above. As shown in , successive additions of glucose to the 0.1 M NaOH solution increased the oxidation current, instantly reaching a stable response in each case in less than ~10 s. The analytical sensitivity was calculated from the slope of a calibration plot (not shown) and was estimated to be 1423.9 μA mM-1 cm-2. This value is ~3 times higher than a previous result for a CoSe nanoflake-decorated reduced graphene oxide electrode. A limit of detection (LOD) value (defined at a S/N ration of 3) of 1.53 μM was obtained, which is also better than previous results. The improved performance of the CoSe electrode described in this study can be ascribed to the fact that no binder was used for the preparation of the CoSe film on the electrode surface. Also, increased active sites due to the porous structure may enhance the performance of the electrode toward glucose oxidation.

elements.content: Cobalt acetate tetrahydrate (Co­(CH3COO)2·4H2O), 2-methylimidazole (CH3C3H2N2H, 2-MeIm), sodium sulfate (Na2SO4), sodium hydroxide (NaOH), selenium powder (Se), sodium hydroxymethanesulfinate dehydrate (CH3NaO3S·2H2O, Rongalite), and glucose were all obtained from Sigma-Aldrich and used without further purification. As needed, the pH of solutions was adjusted with 1 M NaOH.
elements.clean_text:
Materials and Methods

Materials

Cobalt acetate tetrahydrate (Co(CH3COO)2⋅4H2O), 2-methylimidazole (CH3C3H2N2H, 2-MeIm), sodium sulfate (Na2SO4), sodium hydroxide (NaOH), selenium powder (Se), sodium hydroxymethanesulfinate dehydrate (CH3NaO3S⋅2H2O, Rongalite), and glucose were all obtained from Sigma-Aldrich and used without further purification. As needed, the pH of solutions was adjusted with 1 M NaOH.

elements.content: The instrumentation, electrode, and cell details for the voltammetry-EQCM measurements are given elsewhere. All potentials above are quoted with respect to the Ag/AgCl reference electrode. The cleanliness of the Au working electrode surface was checked by cyclic voltammetry in 0.5 M H2SO4 by cycling the potential between 0.8 V and −0.6 V until the voltammetric and EQCM frequency signals were stable. Deaeration procedures and other details of the combined linear sweep voltammetry (LSV)–EQCM measurements (potential scan rate: 20 mV/s) are given elsewhere.
elements.clean_text:
Instrumentation and Procedures

The instrumentation, electrode, and cell details for the voltammetry-EQCM measurements are given elsewhere. All potentials above are quoted with respect to the Ag/AgCl reference electrode. The cleanliness of the Au working electrode surface was checked by cyclic voltammetry in 0.5 M H2SO4 by cycling the potential between 0.8 V and -0.6 V until the voltammetric and EQCM frequency signals were stable. Deaeration procedures and other details of the combined linear sweep voltammetry (LSV)-EQCM measurements (potential scan rate: 20 mV/s) are given elsewhere.

elements.content: X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM) instrumentation details may be found in ref . High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) used a JEOL model JEM-2100F instrument. For the TEM sample preparation, the particles were scraped off the support electrode surface. They were then dispersed by sonication in methanol followed by immobilization on copper grid for examination. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded on an Agilent Technologies Cary 610 microscope spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analysis was carried out on a TA4100 instrument.
elements.clean_text: X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM) instrumentation details may be found in ref . High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) used a JEOL model JEM-2100F instrument. For the TEM sample preparation, the particles were scraped off the support electrode surface. They were then dispersed by sonication in methanol followed by immobilization on copper grid for examination. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded on an Agilent Technologies Cary 610 microscope spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analysis was carried out on a TA4100 instrument.

elements.content: This work has demonstrated a general approach to electrosynthesizing a useful precursor to a technologically relevant material (such as CoSe) within a MOF template. Importantly, it was demonstrated here that very well-defined crystal morphologies can be secured even with the mild conditions typical of an electrosynthesis environment. These morphologies and attributes (e.g., high surface area) can be preserved to varying degrees even through subsequent processing of the precursor material, such as calcination or anion exchange. A practical application related to amperometric glucose sensing was demonstrated. While the examples presented above pertain only to Co-based ZIFs, the methodology developed here should be generally applicable to any metal-containing organic framework.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

This work has demonstrated a general approach to electrosynthesizing a useful precursor to a technologically relevant material (such as CoSe) within a MOF template. Importantly, it was demonstrated here that very well-defined crystal morphologies can be secured even with the mild conditions typical of an electrosynthesis environment. These morphologies and attributes (e.g., high surface area) can be preserved to varying degrees even through subsequent processing of the precursor material, such as calcination or anion exchange. A practical application related to amperometric glucose sensing was demonstrated. While the examples presented above pertain only to Co-based ZIFs, the methodology developed here should be generally applicable to any metal-containing organic framework.

cln_elements.content: For the synthesis of CoSe using MOF-derived Co3O4, a NaHSe solution (as a selenium source) was obtained by heating 50 mL of a 0.2 M NaOH solution containing 0.04 g of Se powder and 0.6 g of rongalite at 80 °C until all Se powder was converted to selenide. After cooling to room temperature, the Co3O4 template deposited on the FTO substrate was dipped into the NaHSe solution to fabricate the CoSe film. The SEM images in A,B revealed that the dodecahedral morphology of ZIF-derived Co3O4 was well-retained in CoSe after anion exchange. EDX analyses of the film showed CoSe with an atomic mass ratio of 1:1 (Figure S7A). Also, EDX elemental maps showed that Co and Se elements were uniformly distributed in the CoSe nanostructure (Figure S7B,C). The HR-TEM image in revealed a well-defined crystalline structure with lattice fringes of 0.20 and 0.31 nm, corresponding to the values of the (102) and (100) planes of CoSe planes, respectively.

After cooling to room temperature, the Co3O4 template deposited on the FTO substrate was dipped into the NaHSe solution to fabricate the CoSe film. The SEM images in A,B revealed that the dodecahedral morphology of ZIF-derived Co3O4 was well-retained in CoSe after anion exchange. EDX analyses of the film showed CoSe with an atomic mass ratio of 1:1 (Figure S7A). Also, EDX elemental maps showed that Co and Se elements were uniformly distributed in the CoSe nanostructure (Figure S7B,C). The HR-TEM image in  revealed a well-defined crystalline structure with lattice fringes of 0.20 and 0.31 nm, corresponding to the values of the (102) and (100) planes of CoSe planes, respectively.

cln_elements.content:
Here, we prepared a cobalt–metal organic framework (MOF) by anodic electrodeposition at room temperature and transformed it first to Co3O4 by calcination. The MOF-derived Co3O4 was then employed as a sacrificial template to fabricate CoSe films via anion exchange with a NaHSe medium. Electrodeposited MOF films showed a uniform and well-defined dodecahedral morphology with a particle size in the 3–4 μm range. The MOF-derived Co3O4 retained the original dodecahedral morphology, and these morphological features were essentially preserved in CoSe derived from the Co3O4 template via anion exchange. Both the parent oxide and the chalcogenide were characterized by a variety of spectroscopic and microscopic methods. The MOF-derived CoSe was demonstrated as a nonenzymatic glucose sensor with an analytical sensitivity of 1423.9 μA mM–1 cm–2 and a lower detection limit of 1.53 μM.

As one example of the practical applicability of the MOF-derived CoSe sample, its performance as a glucose amperometric sensor is presented. displays the amperometric response of CoSe films to glucose at a constant potential of 0.5 V. The CoSe electrode was previously fabricated by the procedure described above. As shown in , successive additions of glucose to the 0.1 M NaOH solution increased the oxidation current, instantly reaching a stable response in each case in less than ∼10 s. The analytical sensitivity was calculated from the slope of a calibration plot (not shown) and was estimated to be 1423.9 μA mM–1 cm–2. This value is ∼3 times higher than a previous result for a CoSe nanoflake-decorated reduced graphene oxide electrode. A limit of detection (LOD) value (defined at a S/N ration of 3) of 1.53 μM was obtained, which is also better than previous results. The improved performance of the CoSe electrode described in this study can be ascribed to the fact that no binder was used for the preparation of the CoSe film on the electrode surface. Also, increased active sites due to the porous structure may enhance the performance of the electrode toward glucose oxidation.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Here, we prepared a cobalt-metal organic framework (MOF) by anodic electrodeposition at room temperature and transformed it first to Co3O4 by calcination. The MOF-derived Co3O4 was then employed as a sacrificial template to fabricate CoSe films via anion exchange with a NaHSe medium. Electrodeposited MOF films showed a uniform and well-defined dodecahedral morphology with a particle size in the 3-4 μm range. The MOF-derived Co3O4 retained the original dodecahedral morphology, and these morphological features were essentially preserved in CoSe derived from the Co3O4 template via anion exchange. Both the parent oxide and the chalcogenide were characterized by a variety of spectroscopic and microscopic methods. The MOF-derived CoSe was demonstrated as a nonenzymatic glucose sensor with an analytical sensitivity of 1423.9 μA mM-1 cm-2 and a lower detection limit of 1.53 μM.

As one example of the practical applicability of the MOF-derived CoSe sample, its performance as a glucose amperometric sensor is presented.  displays the amperometric response of CoSe films to glucose at a constant potential of 0.5 V. The CoSe electrode was previously fabricated by the procedure described above. As shown in , successive additions of glucose to the 0.1 M NaOH solution increased the oxidation current, instantly reaching a stable response in each case in less than ~10 s. The analytical sensitivity was calculated from the slope of a calibration plot (not shown) and was estimated to be 1423.9 μA mM-1 cm-2. This value is ~3 times higher than a previous result for a CoSe nanoflake-decorated reduced graphene oxide electrode. A limit of detection (LOD) value (defined at a S/N ration of 3) of 1.53 μM was obtained, which is also better than previous results. The improved performance of the CoSe electrode described in this study can be ascribed to the fact that no binder was used for the preparation of the CoSe film on the electrode surface. Also, increased active sites due to the porous structure may enhance the performance of the electrode toward glucose oxidation.

metadata.title:
Electrochemical Deposition of a Metal–Organic
Framework and Subsequent Conversion to Cobalt Selenide
